key_title: Key to the species of Goodenia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Goodeniaceae

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Goodeniaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Goodeniaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Corolla 1-sided, fan-like, with the lobes more or less equal; fruit indehiscent, drupe-like; creeping fleshy-leaved herb rooting at nodes, mostly of saltmarsh

Corolla not fan-like, lobes generally not equal (usually the upper pair shorter and/or narrower than lower 3); fruit capsular; plants prostrate to erect, not creeping but sometimes stoloniferous, occasionally in swampy sites, but hardly
Corolla wholly mauve or blotched with purple; leaves lobed, commonly lyrate; strongly aromatic herb or subshrub of rocky areas of Snowy and Macalister River catchments in eastern Victoria
Corolla yellow or yellowish; leaves entire or lobed but very rarely lyrate; habit various but not strongly aromatic (G. ovata occasionally faintly aromatic).
Ovary inferior; sepals 5
ovary superior; sepals 3 or 5
Shrubs or subshrubs with woody stems and cauline leaves, basal leaves absent or ephemeral
Low herbs usually with a basal tuft or rosette of leaves, cauline leaves often also present
Pubescent subshrubs to 40 cm high; leaves sessile or subsessile
Glabrous subshrubs or shrub to 2 m high; leaves petiolate
Leaves more or less erect and appressed against stems; flowers subsessile; western Victoria only
Leaves spreading to some degree, sometimes recurved; flowers pedicellate; Licola and upper Snowy River areas
Plant erect, 0.5–2 m high; bracteoles to 6 mm long; sepals 3–11 mm long; leaves finely and closely toothed, thin-textured, on slender petioles

Plant with  decumbent, ascending to sometimes erect stems, to c. 1 m high; bracteoles to 1.5 mm long; sepals 2–4 mm long; leaves almost entire to faintly or coarsely  irregularly toothed, thick, tapered gradually into petioles; western Victoria only
Bracteoles absent
Bracteoles present
Plant stoloniferous or appearing so; leaves in basal or central radical rosettes and in fascicles at the end of spreading stolon-like stems; western Victoria only
Plant not stoloniferous; leaves in basal rosettes, cauline leaves often also present
Leaves densely glandular-pubescent, sometimes also with simple hairs; outer surface of corolla densely glandular-hairy
Leaves glabrous, strigose, cottony-hairy or with crisped hairs; outer surface of corolla glabrous or with simple hairs
Cauline leaves well-developed, similar to but smaller than basal leaves
Cauline leaves poorly developed, few or absent
Leaves entire, toothed or lobed, never pinnatifid
Leaves often pinnatifid
Leaves glaucous; corolla pale yellow
Leaves never glaucous; corolla deep or bright yellow
Corolla strigose and sometimes cottony outside; indusium glabrous to sparsely hairy below; corolla-lobes not reflexed
Corolla glabrous or with a few crisped hairs outside; indusium densely hairy below; corolla-lobes often reflexed
Indusium notched; corolla to 7 mm long; stems with long spreading hairs
Indusium entire; corolla 8–19 mm long; stems glabrous, strigose or with short antrorse or crisped hairs
Indusium glabrous or with minute bristles on upper lip; exterior of corolla appressed-pubescent; sepals mostly 2.5–3.5 mm long; Dimboola and Kerang districts only
Indusium with prominent bristles on upper lip; exterior of corolla almost glabrous; sepals mostly 3–6 mm long; widespread
At least upper flowers more or less sessile; far East Gippsland only
All flowers distinctly pedicellate
Corolla hairs simple; sepals 1.5–4 mm long; fruit to 4 mm long
Corolla hairs stellate; sepals 4–5 mm long; fruit 5–9 mm long
Flowers in leafless bracteate panicles; pedicels not or hardly longer than flowers
Flowers solitary on long slender axillary peduncles and/or on pedicels much longer than flowers
Panicles mostly up to one and a half times as long as leaves
Panicles more than one and a half times as long as leaves
Sepals 4–7 mm long; corolla 15–25 mm long, orange-yellow with purplish stripes in lower half; indusium c. 3 mm wide, with long hairs on apex; south-west Victoria only
Sepals less than 3 mm long; corolla less than 15 mm long, lemon-yellow; indusium to c. 2 mm wide, virtually glabrous except for a short apical fringe
Indusium notched and folded downwards lengthwise
Indusium not or barely notched and flat or dorsally concave
Leaves mostly narrower than 6 mm, not or indistinctly toothed; corolla mostly less than 10 mm long (occasionally to 13 mm); north-central to north-eastern Victoria
Leaves mostly wider than 6 mm, distinctly toothed; corolla 10 mm long or more; eastern Victoria, south of the Dividing Range
Stems often long, creeping; basal leaves few; cauline leaves many, well-developed
Stems, if present, usually short, ascending; basal leaves many, well-developed; cauline leaves few
Sepals linear, <1 mm wide, glabrescent or with whitish, curled, sometimes felted hairs only; peduncles not or barely geniculate
Sepals elliptic, >2 mm wide, invested with strigose hairs, sometimes with a few fine curled whitish hairs; peduncles usually distinctly geniculate
Upper leaf surface with stellate hairs (usually with some longer simple hairs); mallee areas of north-west Victoria
Upper leaf surface with simple hairs only or glabrescent; widespread, but rare (if present) in mallee areas of north-west
Inflorescences several-flowered on scapes usually far exceeding leaves; largest basal leaves usually wider than 15 mm
Inflorescences single-flowered, shorter than to about twice as long as leaves;  largest basal leaves to c. 15 mm wide
Mature leaves usually white cottony-tomentose on lower surface, glabrescent on upper surface; bracteoles 5–12 mm long; indusium concave
Mature leaves with scattered hairs on both surfaces but not tomentose; bracteoles mostly 3–5 mm long; indusium strongly folded
Sepals 3; leaves almost entire; corolla 7–10 mm long; seed not winged; alps and subalps
Sepals 5; leaves variously toothed; corolla 10–22 mm long; seed conspicuously winged
Bracteoles fused; corolla often with purplish markings, not spurred; far north-west
Bracteoles free or nearly so; corolla wholly yellow or brownish near throat, spurred
Corolla-lobes more or less equal; indusium narrow-oblong; wing around seed 1–2 mm broad; plant glabrous or nearly so; far north-west and Dimboola area
Corolla-lobes unequal; indusium ovate; wing around seed to 1 mm broad; plant usually hairy; widespread
